node.title: Singing the Praises of R.B.G. Style
node.alt: Pretty Yende performing in a Bibhu Mohapatra gown during a dress rehearsal at The Kennedy Center for the Washington National Opera’s new show, “Come Home: A Celebration of Return,” which is inspired by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
node.description: Bibhu Mohapatra and the Washington National Opera pay homage to the Supreme Court justice.
node.content: ["The legacy of Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg has inspired all sorts of cultural paeons since her death in September 2020. They have included an exhibition of the Justice\u2019s mementos at the New-York Historical Society, an upcoming children\u2019s picture book, and an off-Broadway play written by Dianne Nora. But the latest tribute, a new work from the Washington National Opera, may be the most apropos yet.", "\u201cCome Home: A Celebration of Return,\u201d which runs Nov. 6-14 at the Kennedy Center, involves marquee opera singers like David Butt Phillip and Isabel Leonard performing songs that play on themes loosely related to Justice Ginsburg\u2019s life and work: freedom, equality, perseverance. It will be the first in-person production staged by the Washington National Opera since the early Covid-19 lockdowns, and feature not only songs from \u201cFidelio,\u201d \u201cCarmen,\u201d \u201cMacbeth\u201d and \u201cWilliam Tell\u201d but costumes by the New York Fashion Week designer Bibhu Mohapatra.", "Justice Ginsburg was an opera aficionado (the art form played a major role in her friendship with her ideological counterpart, Justice Antonin Scalia), and a longtime supporter of the Washington National Opera. In 2016, the diminutive judge even took on, for one night only, a small, non-singing role in the company\u2019s staging of \u201cThe Daughter of the Regiment.\u201d Beaming throughout her performance and donning an ornate chartreuse gown and dramatic headpiece, she was showered with thunderous applause.", "As much as she loved opera, however, Justice Ginsburg was also finely attuned to fashion, famously accessorizing her court attire with collars in varying styles and materials such as delicate lace, colorful beads and shells. Once, she caught the internet\u2019s attention by wearing a pair of sparkly, \u201cWizard of Oz\u201d-esque heels to the White House. So it was only fitting that when it was time to create the costumes for \u201cCome Home,\u201d the Opera turned to a designer well-versed in colorful, eye-catching fashion: the India-born and New York-based Bibhu Mohapatra.", "\u201cThis is my vision of her,\u201d said Mr. Mohapatra, whose clothes have been worn by the former first lady Michelle Obama and the actress Gwyneth Paltrow.", "The opera\u2019s artistic director, Francesca Zambello, said that Mr. Mohapatra was chosen, in part, because of his work with a previous production of \u201cAida\u201d in 2012, for which the designer delivered an opulent take on Egyptian fashion that drew from his NYFW collections. Ms. Zambello wanted to place a similar emphasis on clothes for \u201cCome Home.\u201d", "\u201cI felt it was important to have a visual thread of attire for all the artists involved,\u201d Ms. Zambello said.", "She added: \u201cRuth Bader Ginsburg was the greatest advocate for everything we do in the opera house. She did so much for our art form by speaking about it publicly and encouraging people to attend \u2014 we should all be incredibly grateful.\u201d", "To that end, Mr. Mohapatra created what he called the \u201coperatic couture\u201d version of the Ginsburg aesthetic: jewel-toned summer gloves, lots of feather earrings, and a voluminous spin on the black robe in the form of ball gowns extravagantly composed of colorful muslins and silks.", "According to the designer, the opera first contacted him about \u201cCome Home\u201d during a particularly difficult period in his life. Mr. Mohapatra was in India for the first time in more than two years, attending the funeral of a brother who recently died of issues related to Covid-19. He received the pitch from Ms. Zambello just as he was touring sections of the subcontinent.", "\u201cFor me, it was important to jump into this because there is no one more American than her,\u201d said Mr. Mohapatra of Justice Ginsburg, adding that after watching hours of clips and videos of the legal icon he has become a committed \u201cR.B.G.-er.\u201d", "\u201cThis is a little bit of my big American dream coming true \u2014 especially as an immigrant,\u201d Mr. Mohapatra said.", "To learn more about the Justice, Mr. Mohapatra turned to the Oscar-nominated 2018 documentary \u201cRBG\u201d and watched interviews on YouTube. Then he scoured India for materials, especially his home state of Odisha, on the east coast of India, where he found rich, colorful ikat fabrics.", "Mr. Mohapatra decided early on to abandon the popular markers of Justice Ginsburg\u2019s fashion \u2014 \u201cCollars were too literal,\u201d he said \u2014 in favor of a more subtle approach. He was especially fascinated by the wide array of gloves Justice Ginsburg wore, such as the fishnet pair she chose for a Time magazine shoot, and used those as a connecting thread for the singers, for whom he made assorted version in peacock tones and lace.", "\u201cThere\u2019s a stealth energy she brought to the table,\u201d Mr. Mohapatra continued. \u201cShe sent a message with the way she dressed.\u201d One of power, he said, and presence.", "In the end, Mr. Mohapatra said, it\u2019s that grandeur of thought he most wanted his designs to convey, and which he will most remember. Justice Ginsburg\u2019s \u201ccareful selection of words, her articulation, her thought process,\u201d he said, \u201cthat is something I am going to keep with me for life.\u201d"]
